Are there any traditions or festivals you look forward to?
Do you notice changes in your daily routine in autumn?
Is there a part of autumn that makes you feel nostalgic?
Do you feel more creative, relaxed, or reflective in this season?
How do you decorate or change your space for autumn?
Are there books, music, or movies you enjoy more in fall?
Do you think autumn has a unique mood compared to other seasons?
phrases: The best thing about autumn for me is...
I always look forward to...
Autumn makes me feel...
tips: Focus on emotional + sensory appeal
Encourage storytelling and seasonal routines
Make room for both fun and reflective tones

title: Have you enjoyed any seasonal events or festivals recently?
examples: Have you been to any autumn festivals or outdoor events?
Do you enjoy cultural festivals, food fairs, or local markets?
Are there any seasonal events in your neighborhood?
What kind of events do you usually go to in autumn?
Have you been to a harvest festival or sports day recently?
Do you prefer large crowds or small community events?
What’s the last outdoor event you attended?
Do you usually go with friends, family, or alone?
Is there an event you look forward to every year?
Have you ever volunteered or performed at a festival?
phrases: Last weekend, I went to...
One of my favorite events in autumn is...
The atmosphere was so lively and colorful!
tips: Encourage discussion of local culture and traditions
Invite vivid descriptions of sounds, foods, and scenes
Compare city vs rural festival experiences

title: Do you celebrate Halloween or enjoy the seasonal atmosphere?
examples: Do you usually dress up for Halloween?
Have you ever carved a pumpkin?
Do you decorate your house or classroom?
Is Halloween popular in your community?
Do you enjoy spooky movies or haunted attractions?
Have you ever gone trick-or-treating (or taken someone)?
Do you prefer cute or scary Halloween themes?
What do you think about Halloween as a cultural event?
Do you enjoy Halloween food or snacks?
Have you ever made or worn a costume you’re proud of?
phrases: This year, I might dress up as...
I don’t celebrate, but I like the atmosphere.
Halloween always reminds me of...
tips: Compare Halloween traditions across countries
Make room for both participants and observers
Focus on the visual and fun side, not just cultural depth

title: Have you gone to see the autumn leaves this year?
examples: Have you visited any spots famous for autumn colors?
Do you have a favorite place to see the leaves?
What’s the best time to go leaf-viewing in your area?
Do you prefer mountains, parks, or temples for viewing?
Did you take any pictures of the trees?
Do you go leaf-peeping alone, with friends, or family?
What color leaves do you like the most?
Do you usually bring snacks or a lunch on these outings?
What kind of atmosphere do you enjoy while viewing nature?
Have you ever traveled far just to see the autumn scenery?
phrases: This year, I went to see the leaves at...
I love the way the colors change in...
The view was absolutely beautiful!
tips: Encourage descriptions of color, light, and sound
Invite comparisons between different years or places
Share small personal traditions (tea, walks, photos)

title: What helps you enjoy cozy, slow-paced autumn days?
examples: Do you enjoy staying home more in autumn?
What’s your favorite drink or snack for relaxing in fall?
Do you read, watch movies, or listen to music more in this season?
How do you make your space feel cozy?
Do you have any evening or weekend autumn routines?
Do you enjoy candles, blankets, or warm lighting?
What kinds of clothes do you love to wear in fall?
Do you journal, reflect, or take things slower in this season?
Is there a time of day that feels especially relaxing in autumn?
What’s one thing that always makes you feel at ease?
phrases: In autumn, I love to slow down by...
My perfect cozy day includes...
I feel most relaxed when...
tips: Focus on mood, texture, and sensory warmth
Encourage sharing of small daily pleasures
Bring in lifestyle details—scented tea, music, lighting

title: Do you enjoy seasonal foods in autumn?
examples: What’s your favorite autumn food?
Have you eaten any sweet potatoes or chestnuts recently?
Do you like cooking with mushrooms or pumpkin in fall?
Do you enjoy limited-edition seasonal items (like from Starbucks or convenience stores)?
Have you been to a restaurant that had a seasonal menu?
Do you change what you eat when the weather gets cooler?
Do you like fruit like persimmons or grapes in autumn?
Have you tried any traditional Japanese autumn dishes?
Do you prefer savory or sweet autumn foods?
Do you have any family dishes you eat only in autumn?
phrases: In autumn, I always eat...
I tried a new dish with...
I love the taste of...
tips: Encourage sharing recipes, food photos, or memories
Great chance to talk about regional foods
Include both home-cooked and store-bought items

title: Have you read any good books or watched any good movies lately?
examples: What book are you reading right now?
Have you seen any interesting movies or shows recently?
Do you prefer reading fiction or non-fiction?
Do you have a favorite genre?
Is there a book or movie you would recommend to others?
Do you usually read or watch things in English or Japanese?
Do you use subtitles when watching movies in English?
Has a book or movie ever changed the way you think?
Do you prefer going to the cinema or watching at home?
Is there a story you’d love to see made into a movie?
phrases: I just finished reading...
I really enjoyed watching...
I would recommend it because...
tips: Encourage sharing summaries or favorite scenes
Good chance to explore language-learning methods too (like reading in English)
People can bring books or movie screenshots to share visually

title: What do you like to do on a chilly autumn day?
examples: What do you usually do on cold weekends?
Do you enjoy taking walks in autumn?
Do you like staying inside with a warm drink?
Have you changed your daily routine as the weather changed?
Do you do any crafts or hobbies at home in autumn?
Do you like visiting hot springs or public baths?
Have you switched to winter clothes yet?
Do you enjoy cozy cafes or bookstores?
What’s your ideal relaxing autumn day like?
Is there anything you always do when it gets cold?
phrases: I love staying in and...
I usually go out to...
It’s the perfect season for...
tips: Encourage sharing of cozy routines or local places
Great topic for discussing personal preferences and moods
Can include foods, fashion, activities, or home routines

title: Do you like any fall traditions or events?
examples: Have you ever participated in any fall festivals?
Do you visit shrines for Shichi-Go-San?
Do you like looking at autumn leaves?
Have you been on any trips recently?
Is there a place you always visit in autumn?
Do you celebrate Labor Thanksgiving Day?
What’s your favorite fall event in your area?
Do you do anything special for November holidays?
Have you taken any fall photos recently?
Are there any events that remind you of your childhood?
phrases: I always go to...
I used to enjoy...
My family usually...
tips: Use this week to invite participants to share memories and local experiences
Good opportunity to compare traditions across cultures
Visual aids (like photos or websites) can enhance the conversation

title: Do you feel the year is ending soon?
examples: How do you feel when December is coming?
Do you start planning for the end of the year?
What kind of things do you want to finish before the year ends?
Do you get busier in this season?
Have you achieved your goals for this year?
Do you send end-of-year greetings or cards?
Do you reflect on the year in any way?
Do you have any end-of-year events at work or school?
Do you like this time of year?
Do you make a to-do list before the new year?
phrases: It’s hard to believe the year is almost over.
I need to wrap things up before the holidays.
This season always feels hectic.
tips: A good time to reflect and share thoughts about the year so far.
Participants can talk about habits, routines, or time management.
Can lead to discussions on goal setting or work-life balance.

title: Do you like winter?
examples: How do you usually spend time in winter?
Do you like the cold weather?
What’s your favorite winter activity?
Have you ever built a snowman or gone skiing?
What’s your favorite winter food or drink?
Do you like any winter holidays?
Do you have any tips to stay warm?
Do you feel more or less active in winter?
What do you wear in winter?
Do you prefer summer or winter? Why?
phrases: I love the crisp air in winter.
I’m not a fan of cold weather.
Hot drinks are a must in winter.
tips: Can include both lifestyle and emotional responses to the season.
Encourage sharing local customs or climate differences.
Consider asking for photos or descriptions of typical winter days.

title: What do you do for the holidays?
examples: Do you have any plans for the holidays?
What does your family usually do for New Year’s or Christmas?
Do you like staying home or going somewhere?
Are you preparing any gifts?
What’s your favorite holiday memory?
Do you celebrate with friends or family?
What kind of food do you usually eat?
Is your holiday season busy or relaxing?
Do you decorate your house?
Do you enjoy holiday music or movies?
phrases: I usually spend the holidays…
My family always…
This year, I’m planning to…
tips: Good time to compare cultural traditions (e.g., Christmas vs. New Year in different countries)
Encourage discussion about holiday foods, events, or break plans
Optional: Bring or show a holiday decoration/photo

title: How do you prepare for the new year?
examples: Do you do a big cleaning at the end of the year?
What’s your must-do before January?
Do you make a to-do list or goals?
How do you organize your home or schedule?
Do you send any New Year cards?
Do you go shopping for the new year?
Do you feel excited or stressed about the new year?
Do you have any customs or habits for this season?
What do you want to finish before the year ends?
How do you relax during this busy time?
phrases: I always clean…
Before the year ends, I try to…
I feel ___ about the coming year.
tips: Encourage students to share cultural or family customs
Talk about both physical and mental preparation
Include productivity hacks or routines

title: Looking back on the year
examples: What was the best thing that happened this year?
Did you achieve any personal goals?
What challenges did you face?
What did you learn this year?
How did your daily life change?
What made you happy this year?
Did you try anything new?
What would you do differently next year?
Who had the biggest impact on you?
If you could describe this year in one word, what would it be?
phrases: This year, I…
One thing I learned was…
Next year, I hope to…
tips: Encourage reflection and storytelling
Use this as a wrap-up session with a positive tone
Good time to build community by sharing personal stories

title: How do you spend New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Day?
examples: What do you usually do on December 31st?
Do you stay up until midnight?
How do you celebrate New Year’s Day?
Do you visit a shrine or temple?
What’s your favorite New Year food?
Do you watch any special TV shows?
Do you set any new year resolutions?
What’s your family tradition?
Do you prefer quiet or lively celebrations?
Have your New Year habits changed over time?
phrases: I usually spend New Year’s Eve…
My New Year’s tradition is…
I like to start the year with…
tips: Great time to compare Japanese customs with other countries
Use this to review cultural vocabulary (e.g., おせち, 初詣)
Ask about past experiences or funny stories
